METS:xmlData.dcterms:title: The significance of Central European border settlements in the work of the North-Eastern Boundary Bureau and the Boundary Commission in Ireland before 1925
METS:xmlData.dcterms:alternative: Pomen urejanja srednjeevropskih mej za delo Urada za severovzhodno mejo (North-Eastern Boundary Bureau) in Mejne komisije (Boundary Commission) na Irskem pred letom 1925
METS:xmlData.dcterms:creator: Zách, Lili
METS:xmlData.dcterms:subject: srednjeevropske meje
Urad za severovzhodno mejo
Mejna komisija
Irska
pred 1925
Central European border
Boundary Commission
North-Eastern Boundary Bureau
Ireland
before 1925
METS:xmlData.dcterms:publisher: Oddelek za zgodovino Filozofske fakultete Univerze v Ljubljani, Ljubljana

METS:xmlData.entity:description: Po koncu prve svetovne vojne so irski nacionalistični krogi zaradi možne delitve Irske zavzeto spremljali rojstvo novih malih neodvisnih držav v vzhodni Srednji Evropi. Iz časopisnih uvodnikov in člankov ter diplomatskih poročil je razvidno, da je bila povojna Irska naklonjena urejanju meja v celinski Evropi, saj je bil razpad Avstro-Ogrske podobno sporen. Ta prispevek preučuje, kako so takratni irski poročevalci dojemali vprašanje urejanja mej v Srednji Evropi, s čimer omogoča vpogled v preoblikovanje političnega prostora na Irskem in v Srednji Evropi. Čeprav je bil spopad med unionisti in nacionalisti glede vprašanja samouprave (Home Rule) del irskih političnih razprav že pred prvo svetovno vojno, je ustanovitev dveh držav na irskem otoku temeljila na zakonu o vladi Irske (Government of Ireland Act) iz leta 1920. Leto pozneje je angleško-irski sporazum omogočil novoustanovljeni državi Severni Irski ločitev od Svobodne države Irske. Pozneje sta bila ustanovljena Urad za severovzhodno mejo (NEBB – oktobra 1922) in Mejna komisija (novembra 1924), da bi popravila (prvo začasno) mejo med Severno Irsko in Svobodno državo Irsko v skladu z željami prebivalcev. Za utemeljitev zahtev je Urad za severovzhodno mejo preučil podobne dogovore o mejah v povojni Evropi. Prispevek se osredotoča na pomen precedensov z ozemlja nekdanje Avstro-Ogrske in njihov vpliv na irsko mejno vprašanje v obdobju 1920–1925. Namen prispevka je prikazati, kako je dejstvo, da so bile meje v središču spora, spodbudilo irsko zanimanje za ozemeljske dogovore v Evropi.

In the aftermath of the Great War, the birth of new independent small states in East-Central Europe was closely followed in Irish nationalist circles due to the possibility of Partition in Ireland. Newspaper editorials, journal articles and diplomatic accounts illustrate that post-war Ireland had an open attitude toward the settlement of borders on the Continent as the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire was similarly controversial. This paper proposes to investigate how contemporary Irish commentators perceived the question of boundary settlements in Central Europe in order to provide an insight into the transformation of political space in both Ireland and Central Europe. Even though the struggle between unionists and nationalists over the Home Rule question had been part of Irish political debates before the Great War, it was the Government of Ireland Act of 1920 that eventually sought to create two states on the Irish Isle. A year later, the Anglo-Irish Treaty allowed the recently formed state of Northern Ireland to opt out of the Irish Free State. Eventually, the North-Eastern Boundary Bureau (NEBB - October 1922) and later the Boundary Commission (November 1924) were established to amend the (first provisional) border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Free State, in accordance with the wishes of the inhabitants. In order to support their claim, the NEBB investigated similar boundary settlements in post-war Europe. This paper will focus on the significance of precedents from the territory of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire and the impact these had on the Irish border question, 1920-1925. Overall, the aim will be to illustrate how the very fact that the question of boundaries was in dispute created a greater Irish interest in territorial settlements in Europe.
